meta.name: Archer Build Workbook: Learn by Creating
meta.description: A hands-on workbook where you BUILD an Archer application from scratch and learn all skills needed to pass the Associate Exam.
meta.target_audience: Complete beginners with zero Archer knowledge and access to on-prem Archer
meta.prerequisites: Access to an on-prem Archer instance with admin/builder permissions

introduction.title: Welcome to the Archer Build Workbook!
introduction.mission: You're going to BUILD a complete 'Security Training Tracker' application from absolute scratch. By the time you're done, you'll know how to create applications, add fields, build forms, create workflows, and everything else needed to SMASH the Archer Associate Exam.
introduction.why_build: Just like learning Archer by creating a D&D character sheet, the best way to learn is by BUILDING something real. You'll start with nothing and progressively add more advanced features until you have a fully functional application.
introduction.what_youll_build: A Security Training Tracker that tracks employee security training completion, with automated workflows, notifications, reports, and dashboards.

part_0_big_picture.title: PART 0: The Big Picture

content: Archer is a **Governance, Risk, and Compliance (GRC) platform**. Think of it as a super-organized digital system where organizations manage:
â€¢ **Risks** - What could go wrong? How likely? How bad?
â€¢ **Compliance** - Are we following regulations? (GDPR, HIPAA, SOX, etc.)
â€¢ **Audits** - Tracking findings and remediation
â€¢ **Policies** - Managing corporate policies and procedures
â€¢ **Third Parties** - Monitoring vendor risks
â€¢ **Incidents** - Documenting and responding to security events
Instead of using messy spreadsheets, emails, and shared drives, everything lives in ONE centralized platform with proper tracking, workflows, and reporting.
**G**overnance - How the organization is run (policies, standards, oversight)
**R**isk - Identifying, assessing, and mitigating threats
**C**ompliance - Following laws, regulations, and standards
**Why does this matter?**
Organizations face massive problems with manual GRC management:
âŒ **Data Loss** - Spreadsheets get corrupted, files get lost
âŒ **Human Error** - Manual updates lead to mistakes
âŒ **No Visibility** - Can't see trends or analyze risks proactively
âŒ **Inefficiency** - People waste time hunting for information
âŒ **Compliance Failures** - Missing deadlines, failing audits
**Archer solves this by providing:**
âœ… Centralized, secure data storage
âœ… Automated workflows and notifications
âœ… Real-time reporting and dashboards
âœ… Audit trails (who changed what, when)
âœ… Integration with other systems

sections.section: How We Use Archer in GRC
content: **Common GRC Use Cases in Archer:**
1. **Risk Management** - Track risks across the organization, assign owners, monitor mitigation
2. **Compliance Management** - Track regulatory requirements, map controls, demonstrate compliance
3. **Audit Management** - Manage audit schedules, track findings, monitor remediation
4. **Issues Management** - Document problems/findings that need resolution (MOST COMMON - seen in almost every solution!)
5. **Third Party Risk** - Assess vendor risks, monitor contracts, track security assessments
6. **Incident Management** - Log security incidents, investigate, remediate
7. **Policy Management** - Publish policies, track acknowledgments, manage exceptions
8. **Business Continuity** - Plan for disasters, document recovery procedures
Archer organizes everything in a hierarchy. You MUST understand this:
**SOLUTION AREA** (Top level)
â†³ Groups of related applications for a business need
â†³ Examples: 'IT & Security', 'Operational Risk', 'Compliance'
**USE CASE** (Pre-built application groups)
â†³ Ready-to-use applications that come with Archer
â†³ Examples: 'Issues Management', 'Audit Management', 'Third Party Risk'
**APPLICATION** (What you're about to build!)
â†³ Houses specific sets of RECORDS
â†³ Can be pre-built (Use Case) or custom (On-Demand)
â†³ Examples: 'Security Findings', 'Risk Register', 'Training Tracker'
**RECORDS** (Individual data entries)
â†³ The actual data (like rows in a database)
â†³ Examples: 'Risk #12345', 'Finding #678', 'Training Record #999'
**Navigation Path:**
Workspace â†’ Solution Area â†’ Application â†’ Records
**EXAM TIP:** This hierarchy is HEAVILY tested! Know it cold!
You're going to build a **Security Training Tracker** application from scratch.
**What it will do:**
â€¢ Track employee security training completion
â€¢ Store training records (who, what training, when, status)
â€¢ Auto-calculate days until expiration
â€¢ Send notifications when training is due
â€¢ Create reports and dashboards
â€¢ Use workflows for approval processes
**By building this, you'll learn:**
âœ“ How to create an application
âœ“ All the different field types
âœ“ How to design forms
âœ“ How to create and manage records
âœ“ Calculated fields and business logic
âœ“ Search and reporting
âœ“ Dashboards and visualizations
âœ“ Notifications and scheduling
âœ“ Data-Driven Events (DDEs)
âœ“ Advanced Workflows
âœ“ Permissions and access control
**AND you'll be ready to SMASH the exam!**

checkpoint: Before moving on, make sure you understand:
â–¡ What Archer is and why organizations use it
â–¡ The problems Archer solves (data loss, human error, lack of visibility)
â–¡ The Archer hierarchy: Solution â†’ Use Case â†’ Application â†’ Records
â–¡ Your mission: Build a Security Training Tracker

part_1_foundation.title: PART 1: FOUNDATION (Easy)
part_1_foundation.subtitle: Building Your First Application
what_youll_learn: How to create an application from scratch
How to add basic fields (text, numbers, dates, value lists)
How to design a form layout
How to create and save records
How to navigate the Archer interface

activities.title: Create Your Application
activities.why_this_matters: Every Archer implementation starts with creating applications. This is the foundation of everything.

details: Navigate to your organization's Archer URL
You should see your default dashboard/homepage
steps.screenshot_tip: If you get lost, click the LOGO in the top left corner to return to your homepage
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: When users log in to Archer, their home view is a Dashboard. Clicking the logo (top left) returns you to your default homepage/workspace.

details: Look at the top menu bar
Click on 'Manage' (you need admin/builder permissions for this)
You'll see a list of existing applications
steps.troubleshooting: If you don't see 'Manage', you don't have admin rights. Ask your Archer administrator to grant you 'Application Builder' permissions.
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Applications house specific sets of Records. To create an application, you need appropriate administrative rights.

details: Look for a button that says 'Add New' or has a green plus icon (+)
A dialog box will appear asking for application details
**Description:** Tracks employee security training completion and expiration dates
**Type:** On-Demand Application (you're building a custom app, not using a pre-built Use Case)
**Acronym:** STT (optional but recommended - makes it easier to reference)
Leave other settings as default for now
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Applications entirely designed and deployed by your organization for specific business needs are called On-Demand Applications. Use Cases are pre-configured and ready to use immediately.

details: You'll see it in the Application Catalog
**IMPORTANT:** Right now, your application is empty - no fields, no forms, nothing. That's what we're about to build!

checkpoint: â–¡ You've successfully created an application named 'Security Training Tracker'
â–¡ You can see it in the Application Catalog
â–¡ You understand the difference between On-Demand Applications and Use Cases
activities.whats_next: Now we need to add FIELDS so we can store data!

activities.title: Add Your First Field (Text Field)
activities.why_this_matters: Fields are where data lives. Without fields, you can't store any information. Think of fields like columns in a spreadsheet.

steps.action: Open Your Application in Edit Mode
details: In the Application Catalog, find your 'Security Training Tracker' application
Click on it to open it
Look for an 'Edit' button or pencil icon
Click it to enter Edit Mode
You should see tabs/sections like: Overview, Fields, Layout, etc.
This is where you define what data your application will store
Right now it's empty (or has only system fields)
Look for 'Add' or 'Add New Field' button
A dialog will appear asking for field type
Select 'Text' (this is the most basic field type)
steps.field_types_overview: Archer has many field types: Text, Numeric, Date, Value List, Cross-Reference, Calculated, Attachments, etc. We'll learn them all progressively.

details: **Description:** Name of the employee who completed the training
**Required:** Check this box (make it a required field)
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Record fields with red asterisks (*) are Required Fields. Users must fill these out before saving a record.

details: You'll see 'Employee Name' in your field list
Repeat the process to add these additional text fields:
- Description: Name of the security training course
- Description: Organization that provided the training

checkpoint: â–¡ You've added 4 text fields to your application
â–¡ You understand that required fields will have red asterisks (*) when creating records
â–¡ You can see all your fields in the Fields list
activities.whats_next: Text fields are great, but we need more field types for a real application. Let's add value lists, dates, and numbers!

activities.title: Add More Field Types (Value Lists, Dates, Numbers)
activities.why_this_matters: Different data needs different field types. Dates for dates, numbers for calculations, value lists for dropdown selections. Using the right field type makes data entry easier and enables powerful features.

details: **Description:** Current status of the training record
Now you need to add the dropdown options (values):
Look for a section to add values - click 'Add Value' for each one
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Value List fields provide dropdown selection options. They're perfect for status fields, categories, or any fixed set of choices.

details: **Description:** Date the employee completed the training
**Description:** Date when the training certification expires
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Date fields store dates and enable date-based filtering, searching, and calculations. You can set up scheduled notifications based on date fields.

details: **Description:** Number of hours the training took
**Description:** Cost of the training in dollars
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Numeric fields store numbers and enable calculations. They're essential for any quantitative data (costs, scores, counts, etc.).

checkpoint: â–¡ You've added 2 Value List fields (Training Status, Training Type)
â–¡ You've added 2 Date fields (Completion Date, Expiration Date)
â–¡ You've added 2 Numeric fields (Training Duration, Cost)
â–¡ Your application now has 10 fields total
activities.whats_next: Now we have fields, but users need a way to see them and enter data. Time to create a FORM LAYOUT!

activities.title: Create Your Form Layout
activities.why_this_matters: Fields define WHAT data you store. Layouts define HOW users see and interact with that data. Without a layout, users can't view or edit records!

details: Make sure you're still in Edit Mode for your application
Click on the 'Layout' tab (might be called 'Views & Layouts' or similar)
This is where you design how fields appear to users
Look for 'Add New Layout' or similar button
**Layout Type:** Record (this is for viewing/editing individual records)

steps.action: Add a Section to Your Layout
details: You should now see a layout designer/editor
Layouts are organized into SECTIONS (like boxes that group related fields)
You'll see your section, and probably a list of available fields on the side
Drag and drop (or select) these fields into the 'Training Information' section:
Arrange them in this order (top to bottom)
Add a new section: 'Dates and Status'
Add these fields to this section:

steps.action: Add a Third Section for Additional Details
Set This as the Default Layout
details: Look for an option like 'Set as Default' or 'Default View/Edit Layout'
This tells Archer: 'Use this layout when users create or view records'
Look for a 'Save' button at the application level (not just the layout)
**IMPORTANT:** Until you publish, users can't access the application!
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: After creating or modifying an application, you must PUBLISH it for changes to take effect.

checkpoint: â–¡ You've created a layout called 'Training Record Details'
â–¡ You've organized all fields into 3 sections
â–¡ You've set this layout as the default
â–¡ You've published your application
activities.whats_next: Your application is now LIVE! Time to create your first training record and see your work in action!

activities.title: Create and Save Your First Record
learning_objectives: Save records properly (don't be like Ruth!)
activities.why_this_matters: This is the moment of truth! You'll create actual data in your application and see everything you built come to life.

details: Click the logo (top left) to go to your homepage
Look for your workspace navigation (left side or top)
Navigate: Workspace â†’ Solution Area â†’ Your Application
You should see an empty list (no records yet)
You'll see a 'New Record' button (Classic UI) or 'Add New Record' (SaaS UI)
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: The correct path to access all records in an application is Workspace > Solution > Application. To add new data, click the New Record icon (Classic UI) or Add New Record (SaaS UI).

details: You'll see the form you just designed!
All your sections and fields should appear
Required fields will have RED ASTERISKS (*)
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Record fields with red asterisks are Required Fields. You must fill them out before you can save.

steps.action: Fill Out Your First Training Record
details: - Training Type: Phishing Awareness (select from dropdown)
Look at the top or bottom of the record
Wait for confirmation (usually a green message saying 'Record saved successfully')
âš ï¸ **DON'T BE LIKE RUTH!** âš ï¸
Ruth's Story: Ruth filled out a record and closed it without clicking Save. When she came back, all her work was GONE. She had to start over.
**THE GOLDEN RULE: ALWAYS CLICK SAVE BEFORE CLOSING A RECORD!**
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: The 'Save' option saves edits to a record. If you don't select Save, your changes won't be kept. This is one of the most common exam scenarios!

details: After saving, you'll see your record in 'view mode'
Note the RECORD ID at the top (something like 'STT-001' or a number)
This unique ID identifies this specific record
Click around and see your data organized in the sections you created
Clicking on a linked Record ID takes you directly to that record
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Clicking on a linked record ID takes you to the record itself. Each record has a unique identifier.

details: Navigate back to the application record list
Create 2-3 more training records with different data:
This gives you test data to work with in later activities!

checkpoint: â–¡ You've successfully created at least 3 training records
â–¡ You saved each record properly (didn't lose any data!)
â–¡ You can view your records in the application
â–¡ You understand that required fields MUST be filled out
activities.whats_next: Congratulations! You've built a working Archer application from scratch! Next, we'll add more advanced features like calculated fields, cross-references, and automation.

what_you_learned: âœ“ Created an On-Demand Application from scratch
âœ“ Added multiple field types (Text, Value List, Date, Numeric)
âœ“ Designed a form layout with organized sections
âœ“ Understood the importance of clicking SAVE!
exam_concepts_covered: âœ“ On-Demand Applications vs Use Cases
âœ“ Different field types and their purposes
âœ“ Navigation paths (Workspace > Solution > Application > Records)
part_1_complete.take_a_break: Take a 10-15 minute break! You've earned it. When you come back, we'll level up with calculated fields, cross-references, and more advanced features.

part_2_building_up.title: PART 2: BUILDING UP (Medium Difficulty)
part_2_building_up.subtitle: Adding Advanced Functionality
what_youll_learn: Calculated fields (auto-calculations based on other fields)

activities.title: Add Calculated Fields (Auto-Calculations)
activities.why_this_matters: Calculated fields do math for you automatically! They save time, prevent errors, and enable powerful business logic. Perfect for things like 'Days Until Expiration' or 'Total Cost'.

details: Calculated fields are GRAYED OUT (read-only) - users can't edit them manually
They auto-populate based on other fields using formulas
They recalculate whenever related fields change
Perfect for: totals, date math, conditional logic
Example: If Expiration Date is set, calculate 'Days Until Expiration' automatically
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Calculated fields cannot be edited manually and change based on other field values. They auto-populate when you save the record.

steps.action: Open Your Application in Edit Mode

details: **Description:** Auto-calculated days between today and expiration date
(The exact syntax might vary - use Archer's formula builder)
This calculates: Expiration Date minus today's date = days remaining
steps.formula_help: Archer has a formula builder with common functions like TODAY(), SUM(), IF(), etc. Use it to build your formulas visually.

details: Add the 'Days Until Expiration' field below 'Expiration Date'
Open one of your existing records
Look at the 'Days Until Expiration' field
It should show a number (could be positive or negative)
If you change the Expiration Date and save, the calculated field updates automatically!
steps.exam_tip: EXAM FACT: Required calculated fields will populate once the record is saved. You can't manually edit them.

details: Create a calculated field called: 'Status Alert'
This will display a text alert based on Days Until Expiration
Add it to your layout in the 'Dates and Status' section
Test it with different expiration dates!

checkpoint: â–¡ You've created 'Days Until Expiration' calculated field
â–¡ You've tested it and see it auto-calculate
â–¡ You understand that calculated fields are read-only
â–¡ (Bonus) You created 'Status Alert' calculated field
activities.whats_next: Next, we'll create cross-reference fields to link your training tracker to other applications (like an employee directory)!
